701053f-b.text:
(1)
Findlay Ave., east side, between East 167th and East 168th Streets, showing the William E. Morris Mansion and a small stone building, said to have been a school house. The Mansion was built in 1816. A frecuent visitor, here, was Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederacy. The Mansion and school have been demolished and on their site now (1938)
stands the Home of the Daughters of Jacob.
Wi'ewC 65Mk9g88-e  1916.
(2)
Another front view of the mansion, facing south.
C;ift of Samuel Landsman  1916.
(3)
A full view of the school house and the rear of the house (right).
The school house is east of the house.
0ift of Samuel Landsman  1916.
(4)
An exclusive view of the school house. In the left background is visible part of the rear of Public School No. 53 facing on East
168th Street.
Samuel Landsnan  9asraooo8o.  1916.
Additonal Note:
Er. Landsman states that the house is near the site of an older house built in 1795 by Jas. Morris. He also ststes thst in the rear of the house, on the easterly end of the lintel over t e fir:t-story
window, were inscriLed t.e initi1s J.M.- 1816.

701054f-a.text:
Findlay Ave., west side, between East 167th and 168th Streets, showing the Morris Farm House,on the former estate of William H. Morris. It was built in 1792,and was demolished between 1900 and 1911 (G.W. Bromley maps). The map of 1923,as revised to September 1932,shows the site to
be still unoccupied.
1898.
Gift of Randall Comfort.
